results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

In this film there are views around Ballarat and members of the Anderson and Bourke families take a trip to the snow. There are some great moments of comedy, beginning with a man and his perilous tower climb, then fun and games at a family card game, then to a pretend plane crash.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:51:00 a man climbs a tower whilst holding his camera and proceeds to take photos from the top after which he comes down and collapses with feigned exhaustion
00:02:18:00 a football field from overhead
00:02:30:00 scenes round Ballarat streets
00:03:08:00 the Buck’s Head Hotel in Ballarat
00:03:16:00 backyard scenes
00:03:20:00 family members playing cards which turns into a comedy when one man pretends to cheat
00:04:09:00 a small plane is ditched in a paddock and we see a man staggering out of the cockpit and collapsing onto the ground feigning injury

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film features a parade of cars, trucks and buses in Ballarat and a visit to a swimming pool where Jack includes some special effects of diving into the pool. There is also a scene where two women are posing for the camera next to a car. It becomes evident that the older stately woman is shy of the camera but the endearing younger woman is very confident as she clowns around in her very 1940s trousers and beret outfit.

This film was originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a parade of vehicles in Ballarat
00:00:50:00 two women stand in front of a car; one is joking around for the camera
00:01:05:00 at a swimming pool, a group of women onlookers watch a men diving into the water; the motion is reversed in a special effect so that we watch the diving in and back out of the pool
00:02:25:00 swimmers give an exhibition of the Australian Crawl (freestyle)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s. A feature of the parade is the Radio Cabs entry which is a car covered in paper flowers. The Radio Cabs company in Ballarat was started by the film maker and his family and friends.

This film contains scenes from a street parade in Ballarat in regional Victoria during the 1940s or 1950s. The parade is in the style of the era - featuring floats made by and promoting local groups and businesses, government departments and marching bands.

Another feature is a large street march of citizens concerned with world peace, conscription, suppression of First Nations people, workers rights, keeping prices down and the atom bomb. It is interesting to note the large contingent of women marching in the parade and the professionally painted banners and placards.

Jack has also captured an exciting motorcycle grand prix at Ballarat which includes spectacular side car racing. Views of the races feature the motorcyclists on their 1940s and 1950s era motorbikes and in protective gear, the haybales used to secure the track, spills around corners and the enthusiastic crowds.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 a large crowd of spectators line up along Sturt St, Ballarat; the Carlyon Hotel can be seen in the background and period cars in the foreground
00:00:17:00 a horse and carriage laden with passengers dressed in historic costume follow a military band in a parade
00:00:24:00 a views down the historic streets of Ballarat and a women’s military band in the passing parade
00:00:47:00 participating floats
00:01:09:00 an air mail float from the Postmaster General’s Department
00:01:16:00 Easter bunny float
00:01:35:00 the Ballarat Scottish Pipe Band followed by a yellow Vauxhall Vyvern model sports car
00:01:50:00 floats pass by including one marking Australian Chinese history in the area
00:03:01:00 an historic and comedic fire brigade float
00:03:31:00 preparing the Radio Cabs float followed by views of the decorated car driving through Ballarat traffic
00:05:14:00 a truck carries a train steam engine in the parade, against a backdrop of Ballarat shops
00:05:32:00 spectators clap and wave as the the Radio Cabs float goes by in the parade
00:05:49:00 title card ‘Children make a colourful display - Ballarat Victoria News Review’
00:07:03:00 spectators at a recreation oval watch large groups of school children marching and performing dances
00:08:51:00 a fair or agricultural show with carnival rides and sideshow tents (possibly the Ballarat Show)
00:09:14:00 an aerial display overhead
00:10:00:00 farm machinery on display
00:10:10:00 a march for peace and other issues in Sydney
00:10:34:00 a large truck festooned with signs such as, ‘Demand World Peace’, ‘Union Leaders Jailed’ and ‘Aborigines Suppressed’
00:10:59:00 a glimpse of the sign for ‘New Theatre’
00:12:30:00 a dramatic fire of a large house or apartment building
00:13:50:00 interview with a motorcyclist followed by racing
00:14:53:00 signs ‘TT Motor Cycles Do Over 100 M.P.H. and ‘1950 Victorian Grand Prix Ballarat’
00:15:16:00 motorcycle riders take off in a race followed by views of the race around the track
00:15:44:00 several riders come to grief on a bend followed by scenes of the race and the crowd of spectators
00:16:51:00 riding over a wet track
00:17:20:00 the track in more open areas
00:18:05:00 sidercar racing
00:18:49:00 Norton model motor bike with side car
00:19:00:00 scenes of the races
00:20:47:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film, ‘The Sequel’, shows various snapshots of his travels almost as if these scenes are the offcuts of other reels. It is more difficult to locate his footage as Kenneth has not included his usual signs and location titles.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:06:00 title ‘The Sequel’ followed by scenes of waterways, a building with razorwire brick fence, houses, sloping green landscapes and various sea vessels back on the water - ferries, larger and smaller boats and sailing boats all in quick succession.

00:02:08:00 a train carrying coal, then more waterways including a road causeway across the water, a large church and a large hill and more water scenes.

00:02:38:00 prosperous looking farmland, market gardens and houses on a hillside, trees and hills and the sea.

00:03:20:00 old, crumbling buildings on a large scale; a newer house and a woman chopping wood followed by scenes of houses. a town street and farmland near a river and hills.

00:04:30:00 ‘Blue Horizon’ title begins a sequence of houses and a town along a river and the sea, Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton walking on the sand.

00:05:35:00 the first of a few upside-down frames appear - a church and a town. These are followed by scenes of a large and possibly industrial country town near the sea.

00:07:17:00 shot of a steam train and an engine reversing into a crowded station.
results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 13]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film, ‘The Sequel’, shows various snapshots of his travels almost as if these scenes are the offcuts of other reels. It is more difficult to locate his footage as Kenneth has not included his usual signs and location titles.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:06:00 title ‘The Sequel’ followed by scenes of waterways, a building with razorwire brick fence, houses, sloping green landscapes and various sea vessels back on the water - ferries, larger and smaller boats and sailing boats all in quick succession.

00:02:08:00 a train carrying coal, then more waterways including a road causeway across the water, a large church and a large hill and more water scenes.

00:02:38:00 prosperous looking farmland, market gardens and houses on a hillside, trees and hills and the sea.

00:03:20:00 old, crumbling buildings on a large scale; a newer house and a woman chopping wood followed by scenes of houses. a town street and farmland near a river and hills.

00:04:30:00 ‘Blue Horizon’ title begins a sequence of houses and a town along a river and the sea, Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton walking on the sand.

00:05:35:00 the first of a few upside-down frames appear - a church and a town. These are followed by scenes of a large and possibly industrial country town near the sea.

00:07:17:00 shot of a steam train and an engine reversing into a crowded station.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a scenic tour of mostly seaside places, from Sydney Harbour and Port Phillip Bay to a brief look at Phillip Island. The Rankine family members feature and are joined by Bob Wootton late in the reel who contributes to their roadside picnic by cooking meat on a barbecue over a fire in a tin. Kenneth uses individual title cards to clearly point out the locations he is filming and fnishes sunset scenes. Kenneth also uses title cards to introduce each sequence.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:12:00 ‘Sydney and the Harbour’, views across the Harbour to residential areas; Kenneth appears to be filming from a vantage point on the water.

00:01:07:00 Harbour Bridge followed by shots of ferries and dockside buildings; a larger ship comes into view as well as Fort Denison Island and a longer shot of the Harbour Bridge.

00:03:20:00 ‘Manly’, the pier and some buildings.

00:03:40:00 shops and shoppers with the camera taking in the view down to the Harbour; beach scenes and a large ship in the distance.

00:04:48:00 ‘Blue Mountains from Echo Point’ is followed by dramatic views over the mountain ranges and rock formations.

00:05::39:00 the Rankines meeting some other travellers along a walking track.

00:05:51:00 scenes of a sports club and members relaxing, the men are in blazers.

00:06:16:00 ‘The Cascades Leura’, waterfalls, a footbridge and Mrs and Miss Rankine splashing at the foot of a waterfall.

00:07:41:00 a band playing in a large rotunda Spanish exhibition dancing for onlookers; this sequence also shows good examples of vintage bathers.

00:08:32:00 ‘St Kilda’, the St Kilda Botanical Gardens.

00:09:17:00 scenes looking across Pier Rd to the St Kilda Pier, kiosk and a yacht followed by shots of swimmers.

00:10:07:00 ‘At Elwood’ shows more examples of vintage bathing costumes with a beach coat and caps and launching a sail boat straight from the sand.

00:11:14:00 ‘At Mid Brighton’ small craft bobbing in shallow waters followed by a yacht race and Kenneth’s daughter with binoculars looking on.

00:13:07:00 ‘At Sandringham’ shows another sequence of swimmers, people sunbathing, sailboats and diving from what might be an old piece of a jetty, sitting on rocks on the shoreline; there are bathing boxes in the background on the beach.

00:16:50:00 a small boat being hoisted down from a shed and rolled on tracks into the water.

00:18:00:00 onwards we see the Rankines joined by Bob Wootton who contributes to their roadside picnic with his meat patties/ burgers, barbecued over a fire in a tin.

00:18:32:00 ‘Phillip Island’ is introduced with a postcard before coastal views and several shots of koalas in trees, the family wandering along a road.

results.title: Fred's Films. Warburton Line 1963
results.brief_description: The ‘Warburton Line’ steam locomotive railway filmed originally in 1963, shows the clean and flowing Yarra River and the lush surrounds of the Yarra Valley as it meanders on its journey. Shot by Fred Daley, steam train enthusiast and 8mm home movie maker, this is a tribute to the Line as two years later “despite opposition, 1965 line closed”. “But the rails are not silent in April 1968” when Fred and friends use a hand-pump rail car to run along the overgrown and forgotten tracks. His inter-title stating: “Now it’s goodbye Warburton June 1968 - perhaps the prettiest broad gauge line of all.” The line found new use years later having been converted to a walking and cycle track but one gets the feeling Fred was right about the use of it as a railway line as this film stands testament to the grandeur and beauty of the original steam adventure.

results.title: Flash trip to the beach
results.brief_description: This home movie takes us back to an era when holidays seemed longer, days sunnier and road safety was much less of an issue. Older Bayside residents will be interested in scenes taken of Brighton streets and the Kinane Street beach. A man and a boy take a trip to the beach on the back of a motorbike.

results.title: Maroondah Dam
results.brief_description:
Silent 1950s home movie footage of a family outing to the Maroondah Dam in the Upper Yarra Valley. Includes images of the landscape and boating facilities. Filmed by portrait photographer Athol Adams.
Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.
description_for_label:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

results.title: Melbourne city parade
results.brief_description: Silent film of the Queen Mother arriving at the Melbourne Town Hall during a Moomba parade. Includes scenes of crowds lining Swanston Street; the Lord Mayor’s welcoming speech to the Queen Mother; and her departure in an open car as she waves to the crowd. Filmed by portrait photographer Athol Adams. Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.
